Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Building Information Model (BIM)-Driven Real-Time Mobile Asset Tracking System for Construction Safety
Award.AbstractNarration:
In the past two decades more than 26,000 U.S. construction workers have died at work. That equates to approximately five construction worker deaths every working day. About 90% of workplace injuries can be traced to unsafe work practices and behaviors. As these statistics indicate, safety in construction remains a big problem. The sad reality of frequent loss of life, injuries, near-misses, and collateral damages poses liabilities that can be prevented. The proposed innovation is to track and monitor location of mobile assets including workers and equipment for improved safety management in dynamic construction job sites with real-time visualization. Given the world's $4-7 trillion dollar construction market, large potential exists for this technology, if successful, to be used worldwide by virtually any owner, contractor, or city that needs or wants safe and healthy construction workplaces.

The proposed technology utilizes wireless tracking sensors and positioning algorithms to display mobile resources in Building Information Models (BIM) in real time. The developed system will undertake safety and health hazard identification at the construction stage of a project and automatically locate workers in real-time, including sending alerts if a worker enters a hazardous area. As the added advantages, the proposed technology can 1) enhance efficiency and reduce time commitment of conducting job hazard analysis and management; 2) improve worker?' safety awareness and their understanding of a surrounding working environment; and 3) collect and store safety knowledge data which will assist to sustain the safety knowledge within the company and help knowledge transfer from experienced professionals to new generations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This research project is to determine a “go” or “no go” for the pursuit of a startup regarding the research in BIM and Safety. The project investigated the technical and commercial feasibility of a location tracking and monitoring system for improved safety management in dynamic construction job sites utilizing Building Information Model (BIM) and Bluetooth Low Energy (BLE) sensor technologies to display mobile assets in BIM in real time.

In regards to the feasibility of a startup with BIM and safety, the research has: 1) participated in the NSF-I-corps class and workshop; 2) interviewed over 100 potential customers during the “customer discovery” phase of the project; 3) developed a minimum viable product (MVP); and 4) traveled to multiple states to meet additional potential customers, construction unions, and business partners for face-to-face interviews. Through the extensive interviews, a significant need was identified for improved worker's safety. In addition, it was found that a reliable tracking system can be acquired with a BLE-based tracking technology. Based on the research outcomes, this research has decided to “go” for the pursuit of a startup regarding the research in BIM and Safety.   

The developed BIM-Safety tracking tool can undertake safety and health hazard identification at the construction stage of a project.  A framework was developed to automatically locate workers in real-time, including sending alerts if a worker enters a hazardous area. New indoor position localization and tracking algorithms were developed for dynamically changing work environments. The system has been successfully implemented both on sample models and real construction projects. The performed research test results illustrate that safety monitoring can be performed in real-time and improve worker’s safety awareness and their understanding of a surrounding working environment.

The BIM and BLE based mobile asset tracking system can radically change the way of current job hazard safety management for the construction industry. The main benefits of the system are to enhance efficiency and to reduce time commitment of conducting job hazard analysis and management. Furthermore, this system can help increase productivity by tracking workers and equipment and reduce wastes by tracking tagged materials, which ultimately benefits the national economy and environment, and society in general. In addition, the historical data produced by the tracking system can be used for engineering education and safety training purposes as well as worker’s behavior-based safety analyses to improve individual worker’s safety habit. The collected safety knowledge data bank can also assist to sustain the safety knowledge within the company and help knowledge transfer from experienced professionals to new generations.
